title: Particle placed at center of square

content.description: Two particles, each with charge <math alttext="positive 10 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>μ</mtext><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, are fixed in place at opposite corners of a square, and a particle with charge <math alttext="negative 20 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>μ</mtext><mtext>C</mtext></math> is fixed in place at one of the other corners, as shown in the figure above. The length of each side of the square is <math alttext="10 centimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cm</mi></math>.
content.question: A particle with charge <math alttext="negative 5 microcoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>5</mtext><mtext> μ</mtext><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in the exact center of the square and then released. In what direction, if any, will it initially move?

choices.label: Toward the top of the page
Toward the bottom of the page

Toward the corner of the square with the <math alttext="negative 20 microcoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>20</mtext><mtext> μ</mtext><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> particle
Toward the empty corner of the square
In no direction, because it will not move

content.answer: Toward the empty corner of the square

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
